div.head: The atheist's tragedy.
Actus primi scaena prima.

sp.speaker: D'amuille.
sp.l: I saw my nephew Charlemont, but now
Part from his father. Tell him I desire
To speak with him.
Borachio, thou art read
In nature and her large philosophy.
Observest thou not the very self same course
Of revolution both in man and beast?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: The same. For birth, growth, state, decay and death:
Only, a man's beholding to his nature
For th'better composition o'the two.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: But where that favour of his nature, is
Not full and free; you fee a man becomes
A fool, as little-knowing as a beast.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: That shows there's nothing in a man, above
His nature; if there were, considering 'tis
His being's excellency, 'twould not yield
To nature's weakness.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Then if death casts up
Our total sum of joy and happiness;
Let me have all my senses feasted in
Th'abundant fullness of delight at once,
and with a sweet insensible increase
Of pleasing surfeit melt into my dust.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: That revolution is too short methinks .
If this life comprehends our happiness,
How foolish to desire to die so soon?
And if our time runs home unto the length
Of nature, how improvident it were
To spend our substance on a minute's pleasure,
And after live an age in misery?

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: So thou concludest that pleasure only flows
Upon the stream of riches.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Wealth is lord
Of all felicity.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: 'Tis oracle.
For what's a man that's honest without wealth?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Both miserable and contemptible.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: He's worse Borachio. For if charity
Be an essential part of honesty,
And should be practised first upon ourselves;
Which must be granted; then your honest man
That's poor, is most dishonest, for he is
Uncharitable to the man, whom he
Should most respect. But what doth this touch me,
That seem to have enough? Thanks industry.
'Tis true. Had not my body spread itself
Into posterity; perhaps I should
Desire no more increase of substance, then
Would hold proportion with mine own dimensions.
Yet even in that sufficiency of state,
A man has reason to provide and add.
For what is he hath such a present eye,
And so prepared a strength; that can foresee,
And fortify his substance and himself,
Against those accidents, the least whereof
May rob him of an age's husbandry?
And for my children; they are as near to me,
As branches to the tree whereon they grow;
and may as numerously be multiplied.
As they increase, so should my providence;
For from my substance they receive the sap,
Whereby they live and flourish.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Sir enough,
I understand the mark whereat you aim.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Silence. Ware interrupted. Charlemont!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Good morrow uncle.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Noble Charlemont;
Good morrow. Is not this the honoured day
You purposed to set forward to the war?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: My inclination did intend it so.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: And not your resolution?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Yes my lord;
Had not my father contradicted it.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: O noble war! Thou first original
Of all man's honour. How dejectedly,
The baser spirit of our present time
Hath cast itself below the ancient worth
Of our forefathers! From whose noble deeds
Ignobly we derive our pedigrees.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Sir, tax not me for his unwillingness.
By the command of his authority,
My disposition's forced against itself.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Nephew, you are the honour of our blood.
The troop of gentry, whose inferior worth
Should second your example, are become
Your leaders: and the scorn of their discourse,
Turns smiling back upon your backwardness.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: You need not urge my spirit by disgrace
'Tis free enough. My father hinders it.
To curb me, he denies me maintenance
To put me in the habit of my rank.
Unbind me from that strong necessity,
And call me coward if I stay behind.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: For want of means? Borachio! Where's the gold?
I'd disinherit my posterity
To purchase honour. 'tis an interest
I prize above the principal of wealth.
I'm glad I had th'occasion to make known
How readily my substance shall unlock
Itself to serve you. Here's a thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: My worthy uncle; in exchange for this,
I leave my bond. So I am doubly bound;
By that for the repayment of this gold,
And by this gold to satisfy your love.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Sir; 'tis a witness (Only) of my love;
And love doth always satisfy itself.
Now to your father; labour his consent.
My importunity shall second yours.
We will obtain it.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: If entreaty fail,
The force of reputation shall prevail.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Go call my sons, that they may take their leaves
Of noble Charlemont. Now my Borachio!

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: The substance of our former argument
Was wealth.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: The question how to compass it.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Young Charlemont is going to the war.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: O, thou beginnest to take me.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Mark me then.
Methinks , the pregnant wit of man, might make
The happy absence of this Charlemont,
A subject for commodious providence.
He has a wealthy father; ready e'en
To drop into his grave. And no man's power
When Charlemont is gone, can interpose
Betwixt you and him.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Thou'st apprehended; both
My meaning and my love. Now let thy trust,
For undertaking and for secrecy,
Hold measure with thy amplitude of wit;
And thy reward shall parallel thy worth.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: My resolution has already bound
Me to your service.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: And my heart to thee.
Here are my sons. —
There's my eternity. My life in them;
And their succession shall for ever live.
And in my reason dwells the providence,
To add to life as much of happiness.
Let all men lose, so I increase my gain,
I have no feeling of another's pain.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I prithee let this current of my tears,
Divert thy inclination from the war.
For of my children thou are only left,
To promise a succession to my house.
And all the honour thou canst get by arms,
Will give but vain addition to thy name;
Since from thy ancestors thou dost derive
A dignity sufficient; and as great
As thou hast substance to maintain and bear.
I prithee stay at home.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: My noble father.
The weakest sigh you breath, hath power to turn
My strongest purpose; and your softest tear
To melt my resolution to as soft
Obedience. But my affection to the war,
Is as hereditary as my blood,
To every life of all my ancestry.
Your predecessors were your presidents;
And you are my example. Shall I serve
For nothing but a vain parenthesis,
I'th' honoured story of your family?
Or hang but like an empty scutcheon,
Between the trophies of my predecessors.
And the rich arms of my posterity?
There's not a Frenchman of good blood and youth '
But either out of spirit or example,
Is turned a soldier. Only Charlemont
Must be reputed that same heartless thing,
That cowards will be bold to play upon.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Good morrow my lord.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Morrow good brother.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Good morrow uncle.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Morrow kind nephew.
What? ha'you washed your eyes wi' teares this morning?
Come: by my soul his purpose does deserve
Your free consent. Your tenderness dissuades him.
What to the father of a gentleman,
Should be more tender than the maintenance
And the increase of honour to his house?
My lord; here are my boys. I should be proud
That either this were able, or that inclined
To be my nephew's brave competitor.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your importunities have overcome.
Pray God my forced grant prove not ominous.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: We have obtained it. — ominous? in what?
It cannot be in anything but death.
And I am of a confident belief,
That e'en the time, place, manner of our deaths,
Do follow fate with that necessity;
That makes us sure to die. And in a thing
Ordained so certainly unalterable,
What can the use of providence prevail?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Morrow my lord Montferrers, lord D'amville.
Good morrow gentlemen. Cousin Charlemont!
Kindly good morrow. Troth I was afeard
I should ha' come too late, to tell you that
I wish your undertakings a success
That may deserve the measure of their worth.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: My lord; my duty would not let me go,
Without receiving your commandments.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Accomplements are more for ornament,
Then use. We should employ no time in them,
But what our serious business will admit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Your favour had by his duty been prevented,
If we had not withheld him in the way.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: He was a-coming to present his service.
But now no more. The cook invites to breakfast.
Will't please your lordship enter. — noble lady.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: My noble mistress! this accomplishment
Is like an elegant and moving speech,
Composed of many sweet persuasive points,
Which second one another, with a fluent
Increase, and confirmation of their force,
Reserving still the best until the last,
To crown the strong impulsion of the rest
With a full conquest of the hearers sense:
Because th'impression of the last we speak
Doth always longest and most constantly
Possess the entertainment of remembrance.
So all that now salute my taking leave,
Have added numerously to the love,
Wherewith I did receive their courtesy.
But you (Dear mistress) being the last and best
That speaks my farewell; like th'imperious close
Of a most sweet oration, wholly have
Possessed my liking, and shall ever live
Within the soul of my true memory.
So (Mistress) with this kiss I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: My worthy servant! you mistake th'intent
Of kissing. Was not meant to separate
A pair of lovers; but to be the seal
Of love; importing by the joining of
Our mutual and incorporated breathes,
That we should breathe but one contracted life.
Or stay at home, or let me go with you.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: My Castabella! for myself to stay,
or you to go, would either tax my youth
With a dishonourable weakness, or
Your loving purpose with immodesty.
And for the satisfaction of your love,
Here comes a man whose knowledge I have made
A witness to the contract of our vows,
Which my return by marriage shall confirm.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: I salute you both with the spirit of copulation, 〈◊〉 already informed of your matrimonial purposes, and will 〈◊〉 testimony to the integrity.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: O the sad trouble of my fearful soul!
My faithful servant! did you never hear,
That when a certain great man went to th'war,
The lovely face of heaven was masqued with sorrow,
The sighing winds did move the breast of earth,
The heavy clouds hung down their mourning heads,
And wept sad showers the day that he went hence,
As if that day presaged some ill success,
That fatally should kill his happiness;
And so it came to pass. Methinks my eyes
(Sweet heaven forbid) are like those weeping clouds,
And as their showers presaged so do my tears,
Some sad event will follow my sad fears.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Fie, superstitious? is it bad to kiss?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: May all my fears hurt me no more than this.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: Fie, fie, fie, these carnal kisses do stir up the concupiscences of the flesh.

sp.speaker: Leuid.
sp.l: O! here's your daughter under her servant's lips.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Madam, there is no cause you should mistrust
The kiss I gave, was but a parting one.

sp.speaker: Leuid.
sp.l: A lusty blood! Now by the lip of love
Were I to choose, your joining one for me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your father stays to bring you on the way.
Farewell. The great commander of the war
Prosper the course you undertake. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: My lord! I humbly take my leave — madam!
I kiss your hand. — and your sweet lip. — farewell.
Her power to speak is perished in her tears.
Something within me would persuade my stay,
But reputation will not yield unto 't.
Dear sir, you are the man whose honest trust
My confidence hath chosen for my friend.
I fear my absence will discomfort her.
You have the power and opportunity
To moderate her passion. Let her grief
Receive that friendship from you; and your love
Shall not repent itself of courtesy.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: Sir, I want words and protestation to insinuate into your credit; but in plainness and truth, I will qualify her grief with the spirit of consolation.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Sir, I will take your friendship up at use.
And fear not that your profit shall be small;
Your interest shall exceed your principal.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Monsieur Languebeau! Happily encountered. The honesty of your conversation, makes me request more interest in your familiarity.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: If your lordship will be pleased to salute me without ceremony, I shall be willing to exchange my service for your favour; but this worshipping kind of entertainment, is a superstitious vanity; in plainness and truth I love it not.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: I embrace your disposition; and desire to give you as liberal assurance of my love, as my lord Belforest your deserved favourer.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: His lordship is pleased with my plainness and truth of conversation.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: It cannot displease him. In the behaviour of his noble daughter Castabella; a man may read her worth and your instruction.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: That gentlewoman is most sweetly modest, fair, honest, handsome, wise, well-born, and rich.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: You have given me her picture in small.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: She's like your diamond; a temptation in every man's eye, yet not yielding to any light impression herself.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: The praise is hers; but the comparison your own.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: You shall forgive me that, sir.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: I will not do so much at your request as forgive you it. I will only give you it sir. By — you will make me swear.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: O! by no means. Profane not your lips with the foulness of that sin. I will rather take it. To save your oath, you shall lose your ring. — verily my lord; my praise came short of her worth. She exceeds a jewel. This is but only for ornament; she both for ornament and use.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Yet unprofitably kept without use. She deserves a worthy husband, sir. I have often wished a match between my elder son and her. The marriage would join the houses of Belforest and Damville into a noble alliance.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: And the unity of families is a work of love and charity.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: And that work an employment well becoming the goodness of your disposition.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: If your lordship please to impose it upon me; I will carry it without any second end, the surest way to satisfy your wish.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Most joyfully accepted. — Rousard! Here are letters to my lord Belforest touching my desire to that purpose.

sp.speaker: Rousard!
sp.p: I send you a suitor to Castabella. To this gentleman's discretion I commit the managing of your suit his good success shall be most thankful to your trust. Follow his instructions, he will be your leader.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: In plainness and truth.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: My leader? does your lordship think me too weak to give the onset myself.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I will only assist your proceedings.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: To say true, so I think you had need, for a sick man can hardly get a woman's good will without help.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Charlemont! thy gratuity and my promises were both but words; and both like words shall vanish into air. — for thy poor empty hand I must be mute:
sp.l: This gives me feeling of a better suit.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Borachio! didst precisely note this man?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: His own profession would report him pure.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: And seems to know if any benefit,
Arises of religion after death;
Yet but compare's profession with his life;
They so directly contradict themselves,
As if the end of his instructions were
But to divert the world from sin, that he
More easily might engross it to himself.
By that I am confirmed an atheist.
Well! Charlemont is gone. And here thou seest,
His absence the foundation of my plot.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: He is the man whom Castabella loves.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: That was the reason I propounded him
Employment fixed upon a foreign place,
To draw his inclination out o'th' way.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: T'has left the passage of our practice free.

sp.speaker: D'am
sp.l: This Castabella is a wealthy heir,
And by her marriage with my elder son;
My house is honoured, and my state increased.
This work alone deserves my industry:
But if it prosper, thou shalt see my brain
Make this but an induction to a point
So full of profitable policy;
That it would make the soul of honesty
Ambitious to turn villain.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I bespeak
Employment in't. I'll be an instrument
To grace performance with dexterity.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Thou shalt. No man shall rob thee of the honour.
Go presently and buy a crimson scarf,
Like Charlemont's. Prepare thee a disguise,
I'th' habit of a soldier, hurt and lame;
And then be ready at the wedding feast,
Where thou shalt have employment in a work
Will please thy disposition.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: As I vowed;
Your instrument shall make your project proud.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: This marriage will bring wealth. If that succeed,
I will increase it though my brother bleed.

div.stage: Enter Castabella avoiding the importunity of Rousard.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: Nay good sir; in troth if you knew how little it pleases me, you would forbear it.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: I will not leave thee, till thou'st entertained me for thy servant.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: My servant? You are sick you say. You would tax me of indiscretion to entertain one that is not able to do me service.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: The service of a gentlewoman consists most in chamber work, and sick men are fittest for the chamber. I prithee give me a favour.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: methinks you have a very sweet favour of you own.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: I lack but your black eye.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: If you go to buffets among the boys, they'll give you one.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: Nay if you grow bitter, I'll dispraise your black eye. The grey eyed morning makes the fairest day.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: Now that you dissemble not, I could be willing to give you a favour. What favour would you have?

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: Any toy: any light thing.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: Fie. Will you be so uncivil to ask a light thing at a gentlewoman's hand?

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: Wilt give me a bracelet o'thy hair then?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: Do you want hair sir?

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: No faith I'll want no hair, so long as I can have it for money.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: What would you do with my hair then?

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: Wear it for thy sake sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: Do you think I love to have my hair worn off?

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: Come you are so witty now, and so sensible.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: Tush. I would I wanted one o'my senses now.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: Bitter again? What's that? Smelling?

sp.speaker: Casta
sp.p: No, no, no. Why now you're satisfied I hope. I have given you a favour.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: What favour? A kiss? I prithee give me another.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: Show me that I gave you then.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: How should I show it?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: You are unworthy of a favour if you will not bestow the keeping of it one minute.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: Well in plain terms, dost love me? That's the purpose of my coming.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: Love you? Yes very well.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: Give me thy hand upon't.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: Nay, you mistake me. If I love you very well, I must not love you now. For now you are not very well, you're sick.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: This equivocation is for the jest now.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: I speak't as 'tis now in fashion, in earnest. But I shall not be in quiet for you I perceive, till I have given you a favour. Do you love me?

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: Then with all my heart, I'll give you a jewel to hang in your ear, — hark ye — I can never love you.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: Call you this a jewel to hang in mine ear? 'tis no light favour, for I'll be sworn it comes somewhat heavily to me. Well. I will not leave her for all this. Methinks it animates a man to stand to't, when a woman desires to be rid of him at the first sight.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I entertain the offer of this match;
with purpose to confirm it presently.
I have already moved it to my daughter;
Her soft excuses savoured at the first
( methought ) but of a modest innocence
Of blood; whose unmoved stream was never drawn
Into the current of affection. But when I
Replied with more familiar arguments,
Thinking to make her apprehension bold;
Her modest blush fell to a pale dislike,
And she refused it with such confidence,
As if she had been prompted by a love
Inclining firmly to some other man,
And in that obstinacy she remains.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Verily that disobedience doth not become a child. It proceedeth from an unsanctified liberty. You will be accessary to your own dishonour if you suffer it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your honest wisdom has advised me well.
Once more I'll move her by persuasive means.
If she resist; all mildness set apart,
I will make use of my authority.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: And instantly, lest fearing your constraint; her contrary affection teach her some device that may prevent you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To cut off every opportunity,
Procrastination may assist her with;
This instant night she shall be married.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Best.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Please it your lordship, my mother attends
I'th' gallery, and desires your conference.
This means I used to bring me to your ear.
Time cuts off circumstance; I must be brief.
To your integrity did Charlemont
Commit the contract of his love and mine.
Which now so strong a hand seeks to divide:
That if your grave advice assist me not,
I shall be forced to violate my faith.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Since Charlemont's absence, I have weighed his love with the spirit of consideration; and in sincerity I find it to be frivolous and vain. Withdraw your respect; his affection deserveth it not.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Good sir; I know your heart cannot profane
The holiness you make profession of;
With such a vicious purpose, as to break
The vow, your own consent did help to make.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Can he deserve your love, who in neglect of your delightful conversation; and in obstinate contempt of all your prayers and tears; absents himself so far from your sweet fellowship, and with a purpose so contracted to that absence, that you see he purchases your separation with the hazard of his blood and life; fearing to want pretence to part your companies? — 'tis rather hate that doth division move; love still desires the presence of his love. — verily, he is not of the family of love.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: O do not wrong him. 'tis a generous mind
That led his disposition to the war:
For gentle love and noble courage are
So near allied; that one begets another:
Or, love is sister, and courage is the brother.
Could I affect him better than before,
His soldier's heart would make me love him more.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: But Castabella. —

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Tush, you mistake the way into a woman,
The passage lies not through her reason, but her blood.
sp.stage: Exit Languebeau, Castabella about to follow.
sp.l: Nay, stay! How wouldst thou call the child,
That being raised with cost and tenderness,
To full hability of body and means;
Denies relief unto the parents, who
Bestowed that bringing up?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Unnatural.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Then Castabella is unnatural.
Nature the loving mother of us all,
Brought forth a woman for her own relief;
by generation to revive her age.
Which now thou hast hability and means
Presented; most unkindly dost deny.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Believe me mother; I do love a man.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Preferrest th' affection of an absent love,
Before the sweet possession of a man;
The barren mind before the fruitful body;
Where our creation has no reference
To man; but in his body: being made
Only for generation; which (Unless
Our children can be gotten by conceit)
Must from the body come. If reason were
Our counsellor, we would neglect the work
Of generation, for the prodigal
Expense it draws us too of that which is
The wealth of life. Wise nature (Therefore) hath
Reserved for an inducement to our sense,
Our greatest pleasure in that greatest work.
Which being offered thee; thy ignorance
Refuses, for th'imaginary joy
Of an unsatisfied affection, to
An absent man. Whose blood once spent i'th' war;
Then he'll come home, sick, lame and impotent;
And wed thee to a torment; like the pain
Of Tantalus, continuing thy desire,
With fruitless presentation of the thing
It loves; still moved, and still unsatisfied.

div.stage: Enter Belforest, Da'mville, Rousard, Sebastian, Languebeau, etc.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now Levidulcia! Hast thou yet prepared
My daughter's love to entertain this man?
Her husband here?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I'm but her mother in-law;
Yet if she were my very flesh and blood,
I could advise no better for good.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: Sweet wife! Thy joyful husband thus salutes thy cheek.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: My husband? O! I am betrayed. —
Dear friend of Charlemont! your purity
Professes a divine contempt o'th' world;
Oh be not bribed by that you so neglect,
In being the world's hated instrument,
To bring a just neglect upon yourself! —
Dear father! let me but examine my
Affection. — sir, your prudent judgement can
Persuade your son that 'tis improvident
To marry one whose disposition, he
Did ne'er observe. — good sir, I may be of
A nature so unpleasing to your mind;
Perhaps you'll curse the fatal hour wherein
You rashly married me.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: My lord Belforest!
I would not have her forced against her choice.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Passion o'me thou peevish girl. I charge
Thee by my blessing, and th'authority
I have to claim th'obedience; marry him.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Now Charlemont! O my presaging tears!
This sad event hath followed my sad fears.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: A rape, a rape, a rape!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Why what is't but a rape to force a wench to marry, since it forces her to lie with him she would not?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Verily, his tongue is an unsanctified member.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Verily, your gravity becomes your perished soul, as hoary mouldiness does rotten fruit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Cousin, you're both uncivil and profane.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Thou disobedient villain; get thee out of my sight. Now by my soul I'll plague thee for this rudeness.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Come; set forward to the church.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p:
And verify the proverb. The nearer the church; the further from God. — poor wench. For thy sake, may his hability die in his appetite; that thou beest not troubled
with him thou lovest not. May his appetite move thy desire to another man: so he shall help to make himself cuckold. And let that man be one that he pays wages too: so thou shalt profit by him thou hatest. Let the chambers be matted, the hinges oiled, the curtain rings silenced, and the chambermaid hold her peace at his own request, that he may sleep the quietlier. And in that sleep let him be soundly cuckolded. And when he knows it, and seeks to sue a divorce; let him have no other satisfaction than this: he lay by and slept: the law will take no hold of her, because he winked at it.

div.head: Actus secundi scaena prima.
div.stage: Music. A banquet. In the night.
Enter D'amville, Belforest, Levidulcia, Rousard, Castabella, Languebeau Snuffe, at one door. At the other door, Cataplasma and Soquette, ushered by Fresco.

sp.speaker: Levidulcia.
sp.p: Mistress Cataplasma! I expected you an hour since.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.p: Certain ladies at my house (Madam) detained me; otherwise I had attended your ladyship sooner.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: We are beholding to you for you company. My lord; I pray you bid these gentlewomen welcome: they're my invited friends.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Gentlewomen, you're welcome, pray sit down.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Frisco! by my lord D'amville's leave I prithee go into the buttery. Thou shalt find some o'my men there; if they bid thee not welcome, they are very loggerheads.

sp.speaker: ●res
sp.p: If your logger heads will not, your hogsheads shall madam, if I get into the buttery.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: That fellow's disposition to mirth should be our present example. Let's be grave and meditate, when our affairs require our seriousness. 'tis out of season to be heavily disposed.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: We should be all wound up into the key of mirth.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: The music there.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Where's my lord Montferrers? Tell him here's a room attends him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Heaven give your marriage that I am deprived of, joy.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: My lord Belforest! Castabella's health. D'amville drinks. set open 'The cellar doors, and let this health go freely round the house. — another to your son, my lord; to noble Charlemont . He is a soldier. Let the instruments of wary congratulate his memory. —

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: My lord, here's one i'th' habit of a soldier says he is newly returned from Ostend, and has some business of import to speak.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Ostend! let him come in. My soul foretells he brings the news will make our music full. My brother's joy would do't: and here comes he will raise it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: O my spirit, it does dissuade my tongue to question him, as if it knew his answer would displease.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Soldier! what news? we heard a rumour of a blow you gave the enemy.

sp.speaker: Bor
sp.p: 'Tis very true my lord.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Canst thou relate it.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: I prithee do.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: The enemy, defeated of a fair
Advantage by a flattering stratagem;
Plants all th' artillery against the town.
Whose thunder and lightning made our bulwarks shake;
And threatened in that terrible report,
The storm wherewith they meant to second it.
Th'assault was general. But for the place
That promised most advantage to be forced;
The pride of all their army was drawn forth,
And equally divided into front,
and rear. They marched. And coming to a stand,
Ready to pass our channel at an ebb,
W'advised it for our safest course, to draw
Our sluices up and make't unpassable.
Our governor opposed; and suffered 'em
To charge us home e'en to the rampiers foot.
But when their front was forcing up our breach,
At push o'pike, then did his policy
Let go the sluices, and tripped up the heels
Of the whole body of their troop, that stood
Within the violent current of the stream.
Their front beleaguered twixt the water and
The town; seeing the flood was grown too deep,
To promise them a safe retreat; exposed
The force of all their spirits, (Like the last
Expiring gasp of a strong hearted man)
Upon the hazard of one charge; but were
Oppressed and fell. The rest that could not swim,
Were only drowned; but those that thought to scape
By swimming, were by murderers that flankerd,
The level of the flood both drowned and slain.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Now by my soul (Soldier) a brave service.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: O what became of my dear Charlemont?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Walking next day upon the fatal shore,
Among the slaughtered bodies of their men,
Which the full-stomacked sea had cast upon
The sands, it was m'vnhappy chance to light
Upon a face, whose favour when it lived
My astonished mind informed me I had seen.
He lay in's armour; as if that had been
His coffin, and the weeping sea (Like one;
Whose milder temper doth lament the death
Of him whom in his rage he slew) runs up
The shore; embraces him; kisses his cheek,
Goes back again and forces up the sands
To bury him; and every time it parts,
Sheds tears upon him; till at last (As if
it could no longer endure to see the man
Whom it had slain, yet loath to leave him;) with
A kind of unresolved unwilling pace,
Winding her waves one in another, like
A man that folds his arms, or wrings his hands
For grief; ebbed from the body and descends:
As if it would sink down into the earth,
And hide itself for shame of such a deed.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: And soldier; who was this?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: O Charlemont!

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Your fear hath told you that whereof my grief
Was loath to be the messenger.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.p: O God.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Charlemont drowned? Why how could that be? since it was the adverse party that received the overthrow.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: His forward spirit pressed into the front;
And being engaged within the enemy,
When they retreated through the rising stream;
I'the violent confusion of the throng
Was overborne and perished in the flood.
And here's the sad remembrance of his life, — the scarf.
Which for his sake I will for ever wear.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Torment me not with witnesses of that,
Which I desire, not to believe; yet must.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Thou art a screechowl; and dost come i'night
To be the cursed messenger of death.
Away. Depart my house; or (By my soul)
You'll find me a more fatal enemy,
Then ever was Ostend. Be gone. Dispatch.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Sir was my love.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Your love to vex my heart with that I hate?
Hark, do you hear? you, knave? —
O thou'rt a most delicate sweet eloquent villain!

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Was't not well counterfeited?

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Rarely. — be gone. I will not here reply.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Why then farewell. I will not trouble you.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: So. The foundation's laid. Now by degrees,
The work will rise and soon be perfected.
O this uncertain state of mortal man!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What then? it is th'inevitable fate
Of all things underneath the moon.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: 'Tis true.
Brother for health's sake overcome your grief.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I cannot sir. I am uncapable
Of comfort. My turn will be next. I feel
Myself not well.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: You yield too much to grief.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: All men are mortal. The hour of death is uncertain. Age makes sickness the more dangerous. And grief is subject to distraction. You know not how soon you may be deprived of the benefit of sense. In my understanding (Therefore) you shall do well if you be sick to set your state in present order. Make your will.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: I have my wish. — lights for my brother.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I'll withdraw a while;
And crave the honest counsel of this man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: With all my heart. I pray attend him sir.
This next room please your lordship.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Where you will.

sp.speaker: Leuid.
sp.p: My daughter's gone. Come son. Mistress Cataplasma, come; we'll up into her chamber. I'd fain see how she entertains the expectation of her husband's bedfellowship.

sp.speaker: Rou.
sp.p: I'faith howsoever she entertains it; I shall hardly please her; therefore let her rest.

sp.speaker: Le●id.
sp.l: Nay, please her hardly and you please her best.

div.stage: Enter 3. Servants drank, drawing in Fresco.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: Boy! fill some drink boy.

sp.speaker: Fresco.
sp.p: Enough good sir; not a drop more by this light.
Not by this light? Why then put out the candles and we'll drink i'the dark and t'wut old boy.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: No, no, no, no, no.
Why then take thy liquor. A health Fresco.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: Your health will make me sick sir.
Then 'twill bring you o'your knees I hope sir.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: May I not stand and pledge it sir?
I hope you will do as we do.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: Nay then indeed I must not stand, for you cannot.
Well said old boy.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: Old boy, you'll make me a young child anon: for if I continue this, I shall scarce be able to go alone.
My body is as weak as water, Fresco.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: Good reason sir, the beer has sent all the malt up into your brain, and left nothing but the water in your body.

div.stage: Enter D'amville and Borachio closely observing their drunkenness.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Borachio! seest those fellows?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Their drunkenness that seems ridiculous,
Shall be a serious instrument, to bring
Our sober purposes to their success.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: I am prepared for th'execution, sir.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Cast off this habit, and about it straight.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Let them drink healths, and drown their brains i'the flood; I'll promise them they shall be pledged in blood.
You ha'left a damnable snuff here.
Do you take that in snuff sir?
You are a damnable rogue then. —

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Fortune I honour thee. My plot still rises, according to the model of mine own desires. — lights for my brother. — what ha'you drunk yourselves mad you knaves.
My lord the jacks abused me.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: I think they are the jacks indeed that have abused thee, dost hear? that fellow is a proud knave. He has abused thee. As thou goest over the fields by and by, in lighting my brother home, I'll tell thee what' shalt do. Knock him over the pate with thy torch, I'll bear the out in't.
I will sing the goose by this torch.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Dost hear; fellow. Seest thou that proud knave, I have given him a lesson for his sauciness. Has wronged thee. I'll tell thee what' shalt do: as we go over the fields by and by, clap him suddenly o'er the coxcomb with thy torch, I'll bear thee out in't.
I will make him understand as much.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Now monsieur snuff! What has my brother done?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Made his will; and by that will made you his heir; with this proviso, that as occasion shall hereafter move him; he may revoke or alter it when he pleases.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Yes. Let him if he can. — I'll make it sure from his revoking.

div.stage: Enter Montferrers and Belforest, attended with lights.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Brother now good night.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: The sky is dark, we'll bring you o'er the fields.
Who can but strike, wants wisdom to maintain:
He that strikes safe and sure, has heart and brain.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: O love! thou chaste affection of the soul,
Without th'adulterate mixture of the blood;
That virtue which to goodness addeth good:
The minion of heaven's heart. Heaven! is't my fate
For loving that thou lovest to get thy hate?
Or was my Charlemont thy chosen love?
And therefore hast received him to thyself?
Then I confess thy anger's not unjust.
I was thy rival yet to be divorced
From love, has been a punishment enough.
(Sweet heaven) without being married unto hate,
Hadst thou been pleased: oh double misery!
Yet since thy pleasure hath inflicted it,
If not my heart, my duty shall submit.

div.stage: Enter Levidulcia, Rousard, Cateplasma, Soquerte, and Fresco with a lanthorn .

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Mistress Cataplasma, good night. I pray when your man has brought you home, let him return and light me to my house.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.p: He shall instantly wait on your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Good mistress Cataplasma; for my servants are all drunk; I cannot be beholding to 'em for their attendance. Exeunt Cataplasma, Soquette, and Fresco.o here's your bride.

sp.speaker: Rous.
sp.p: And melancholic too, methinks .

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: How can she choose? your sickness will
Distaste th'expected sweetness o'the night.
That makes her heavy.

sp.speaker: Rou.
sp.l: That should make her light.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Look you to that.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: What sweetness speak you of?
The sweetness of the night consists in rest.

sp.speaker: Rou.
sp.l: With that sweetness thou shalt be surely blessed,
Unless my groaning wake thee. Do not moan.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: She'd rather you would wake, and make her groan.

sp.speaker: Rou.
sp.l: Nay'troth sweet heart, I will not trouble thee.
Thou shalt not lose thy maidenhead too night.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: O might that weakness ever be in force;
I never would desire to sue divorce!

sp.speaker: Rou.
sp.l: Wilt go to bed.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: I will attend you, sir.

sp.speaker: Rou.
sp.l: Mother, good night.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Pleasure be your bedfellow.
Why sure their generation was asleep,
When she begotten those dormice; that she made
Them up so weakly and imperfectly.
One wants desire; the tother hability.
When my affection even with their cold bloods
(As snow rubbed through an active hand, does make
The flesh to burn) by agitation is
inflamed. I could unbrace, and entertain
The air to cool it.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: That but mitigates
The heat; rather embrace and entertain
A younger brother; he can quench the fire.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Can you so, sir? now I beshrew your ear.
Why bold Sebastian, how dare you approach
So near the presence of your displeased father.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Under the protection of his present absence.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Belike you knew he was abroad then.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Yes.
Let me encounter you so; I'll persuade
Your means to reconcile me to his love.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Is that the way? I understand you not.
But for your reconcilement, meet m'at home;
I'll satisfy your suit

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Within this half hour?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Or within this whole hour. When you will. — a lusty blood! has both the presence and the spirit of a man. I like the freedom of his behaviour. — ho — Sebastian! Gone? — has set my blood a-boiling i'my veins and now (Like water poured upon the ground, that mixes itself with every moisture it meets) I could clasp with any man. Enter Fresco with a lantern.o Fresco! Art thou come? If tother fail, than thou art entertained.
sp.l: Lust is a spirit, which whosoever doth raise;
The next man that encounters boldly, lays.

div.stage: Enter Borachio warily and hastily over the stage, with a s●one in eyther hand.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Such stones men use to raise a house upon;
But with these stones I go to ruin one.

div.stage: Enter two servants drunk fighting with their torches, D'amville, Montferrers, Belforest, and Languebeau Snuffe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Passion o'me you drunken knaves: you'll put the lights out.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: No my lord; they're but in jest.
Mine's out.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Then light it at his head, that's light enough. — fore-god, they're out. You drunken rascals back and light 'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Tis exceeding dark.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: No matter. I am acquainted with the way. Your hand. Let's easily walk. I'll lead you till they come.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: My soul's oppressed with grief. T'lies heavy at my heart, oh my departed son! ere long I shall be with thee

div.stage: D'amville thrusts him down into the gravel pit.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Marry God forbid.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: O, o, o.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Now all the host of heaven forbid. Knaves, rogues.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pray God he be not hurt! here's fallen into the gravel pit.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Brother! dear brother! Rascals, villains, knaves. Enter the servants with lights.eternal darkness damn you; come away. Go round about into the gravel pit, and help my brother up. Why what a strange unlucky night is this? Is't not my lord? I think that dog that howled the news of grief, that fatal screechowl ushered on this mischiefs.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Mischief indeed my lord. Your brother's dead.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: He's dead.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: He's dead.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p:
Dead be your tongues. Drop out mine eyeballs, and let envious fortune play at tennis with 'em. Have I lived to this? Malicious nature! hadst thou born me blind; thou'dst yet been something favourable to me. No breath? No motion? Prithee tell me heaven! hast shut thine eye to wink at murder; or hast put this sable garment on, to mourn at's death? Not one poor spark in the whole spacious sky, of all that endless number would vouchsafe to shine? You viceroys to the King of nature! whose constellations govern mortal births; where is that fatal planet ruled at his nativity? That might ha' pleased to light him out, as well into th'world; unless it be ashamed
to have been the instrument of such a good man's cursed destiny. —

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.l: Passions transports you. Recollect yourself.
〈◊〉 him not. Whether our deaths be good
Or bad; it is not death but life that tries;
He lived well, (Therefore) questionless, well dies.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: I. 'tis an easy thing for him that has no pain to talk of patience. Do you think that nature has no feeling?

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Feeling? Yes. But has she purposed any thing for nothing? What good receives this body by your grief? Whether is't more unnatural not to grieve for him you cannot help with it; or hurt yourself with grieving and yet grieve in vain?

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Indeed had he been taken from me like a piece o'dead flesh, I should neither ha' felt it, nor grieved for't. But come hither, pray look here. Behold the lively tincture of his blood! Neither the dropsy nor the jaundice in't. But the true freshness of a sanguine red; for all the fog of this black murderous night has mixed with it. For any thing I know, he might ha' lived till doomsday, and ha' done more good than either you or I. Oh brother ! he was a man of such a native goodness; as if regeneration had been given him in his mother's womb. So harmless, that rather than ha' trod upon a worm, he would ha' shunned the way. So dear pitiful, that e'er the poor could ask his charity with dry eyes, he gave 'em relief wi' teares — with tears — yes faith with tears.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: Take up the corpse. For wisdom's sake let reason fortify this weakness.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Why what would you ha' me do? Foolish nature will have her course in spite o'wisdom. But I have e'en done. All these words were but a great wind, and now this shower of tears has laid it, I am calm again. You may set forward when you will. I'll follow you, like one that must and would not.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: Our opposition will but trouble him.

sp.speaker: Belf.
sp.p: The grief that melts to tears, by itself is spent, passion resisted, grows more violent.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Here's a sweet comedy. T'begins with o dolentis, and concludes with ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: O my echo! I could stand reverberating this sweet musical air of joy, till I had perished my sound lungs with violent laughter. Lovely night-raven! thou'st seized a carcase.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Put him out on's pain. I lay so fitly underneath the bank from whence he fell; that e'er his faltring tongue could utter double oo; I knocked out's brains with this fair ruby. And had another stone just of this form and bigness ready: that I laid i'the broken skull upo'the ground for's pillow; against the which they thought he fell and perished.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Upon this ground I'll build my manor-house;
And this shall be the chiefest corner stone.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: T'has crowned the most judicious murder, that
The brain of man was e'er delivered of.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: I. Mark the plot. Not any circumstance
That stood within the reach of the design,
Of persons, dispositions, matter, time or place,
But by this brain of mine, was made
An instrumental help; yet nothing from
Th'induction to th'accomplishment seemed forced,
Or done o'purpose, but by accident.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: First, my report that Charlemont was dead,
Though false; yet covered with a mask of truth.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Ay, and delivered in as fit a time.
When all our minds so wholly were possessed
With one affair, that no man would suspect
A thought employed for any second end.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Then the precisian to be ready, when
Your brother spoke of death, to move his will.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: His business called him thither; and it fell
Within his office; unrequested to't.
From him it came religiously; and saved
Our project from suspicion: which if I
Had moved had been endangered.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Then your healths.
Though seeming but the ordinary rites,
And ceremonies due to festivals: —

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Yet used by me to make the servants drunk.
An instrument the plot could not have missed.
Was easy to set drunkards by the ears:
They'd nothing but their torches to fight with;
And when those lights were out;

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Then darkness did
Protect the execution of the work,
Both from prevention and discovery.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Here was a murder bravely carried, through
The eye of observation, unobserved.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: And those that saw the passage of it, made
The instruments yet knew not what they did.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: That power of rule philosophers ascribe
To him they call the supreme of the stars;
Making their influences governors
Of sublunary creatures; when their selves
Are senseless of their operations.
sp.p: What! dost start at thunder? Credit my belief, 'tis a mere effect of nature. An exhalation hot and dry, involved within a watery vapour i'the middle religion of the air. Whose coldness congealing that thick moisture to a cloud: the angry exhalation shut within a prison of contrary quality, strives to be free; and with the violent eruption through the grossness of that cloud; makes this noise we hear.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: 'Tis a fearful noise.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p:
'Tis a brave noise. And methinks graces our accomplished project, as a peal of ordnance does a triumph. It speaks encouragement. Now nature shows thee how it savoured our performance; to forbear this noise when we set forth, because it should not terrify my brothers going home; which would have dashed our purpose: to forbear this lightning in our passage, lest it should ha' warned him o'the pitfall. Then propitious nature winked at our proceedings;
now it doth express, how that forbearance favoured our success.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You have confirmed me. For it follows well;
That nature (Since herself decay doth hate)
Should favour those that strengthen their estate.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Our next endeavour is; since on the false report that Charlemont is dead, depends the fabric of the work; to credit that with all the countenance we can.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Faith sir, even let his own inheritance, whereof you've dispossessed him, countenance the act. Spare so much out of that, to give him a solemnity of funeral. 'twill quit the cost; and make your apprehension of his death appear more confident and true.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: I'll take thy counsel. Now farewell black night;
Thou beauteous mistress of a murderer:
To honour thee, that hast accomplished all;
I'll wear thy colours at his funeral.

div.stage: Enter Levidulcia into her chamber maned by Fresco.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Thou'rt welcome into my chamber; Fresco. Prithee shut the door. — nay thou mistakest me. Come in and shut it.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: 'Tis somewhat late madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: No matter. I have somewhat to say to thee. What? is not thy mistress towards a husband yet?

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: Faith madam, she has suitors. But they will not suit her methinks . They will not come off lustily it seems.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: They will not come on lustily, thou wouldst say.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: I mean (Madam) they are not rich enough.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: But I (Fresco) they are not bold enough. Thy mistress is of a lively attractive blood Fresco . And in troth she's o'my mind for that. A poor spirit is poorer than a poor purse. Give me a fellow that brings not only temptation with him, but has the activity of wit, and audacity of spirit to apply every word and gesture of a woman's speech and behaviour to his own desire; and make her believe she's the suitor herself. Never give back till he has made her yield to 'It.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: Indeed among our equals madam; but otherwise we shall be put horribly out o'countenance.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Thou art deceived, Fresco. Ladies are as courteous as yeomen's wives, and methinks they should be more gentle. Hot diet and soft ease makes 'em (Like wax always kept warm) more easy to take impression. — prithee untie my shoe. — what? art thou shamefaced too? Go roundly to work man. My leg is not gouty: 'twill endure the feeling I warrant thee come hither Fresco; thine ear. — 'sdainty; I mistook the place. I missed thine ear and hit thy lip.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: Your ladyship has made me blush.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: That shows thou'rt full o'lusty blood and thou knowest not how to use it. Let me see thy hand. Thou shouldst not be shamefaced by thy hand, Fresco. Here's a brawny flesh and a hairy skin: both signs of an able body. I do not like these phlegmatic, smooth-skinned, soft-fleshed fellows. They are like candied suckets, when they begin to perish; which I would always empty my closet off, and give 'em my chambermaid. — I have some skill in palmistry: by this line that stands directly against me; thou shouldst be near a good fortune. Fresco, if thou hadst the grace to entertain it.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: O what is that madam? I pray!

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: No less than the love of a fair lady, if thou dost not lose her with faintheartedness.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: A lady, madam? alas a lady is a great thing, I cannot compass her.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: No? Why? I am a lady, am I so great I cannot be compassed? Clasp my waist and try.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: I could find i'my heart madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p:
Uds body; my husband! Faint-hearted fool! I think thou wert begotten between the north-pole, and the congealed passage. Now like an ambitious coward that betrays himself with fearful delay: you must suffer for the treason you never committed. Go hide thyself behind yond arras, instantly.
Fresco hides himself enter Sebastian.Sebastian! What do you here so late?

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Nothing yet; but I hope I shall. —

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: You're very bold.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: And you very valiant; for you met me at full career.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: You come to ha' me move your father's reconciliation. I'll write a word or two i'your behalf.

sp.speaker: Seba
sp.p: A word or two, madam? that you do for me, will not be contained in less than the compass of two sheets. But in plain terms, shall we take the opportunity of privateness?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: To dance the beginning of the world after the English manner.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Why not after the French or Italian?

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Fie. They dance it preposterously; backward.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Are you so active to dance?

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: I can shake my heels.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: You're well made for't.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Measure me from top to toe; you shall not find me differ much from the true standard of proportion.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I think I am accursed. Sebastian! There's one at the door has beaten opportunity away from us. In brief, I love thee. And it shall not be long before I give thee a testimony of it. To save thee now from suspicion; do no more but draw thy rapier; chase thyself; and when he comes in, rush by without taking notice of him. Only seem to be angry, and let me alone for the rest.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Now by the hand of Mercury.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What's the matter wife?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Oh, oh, husband!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Prithee what ailest thou woman?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: O feel my pulse. It beats I warrant you. Be patient a little sweet husband; tarry but till my breath come to me again, and I'll satisfy you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What ails Sebastian, he looks so distractedly?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: The poor gentleman's almost out on's wits I think. You remember the displeasure his father took against him about the liberty of speech he used even now when your daughter went to be married.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, what of that?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: T'has crazed him sure: he met a poor man i'the street even now. Upon what quarrel I know not: but he pursued him so violently, that if my house had not been his rescue; he had surely killed him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What a strange desperate young man is that!

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Nay husband, he grew so in rage when he saw the man was conveyed from him, that he was ready even to have drawn his naked weapon upon me. And had not your knocking at the door prevented him; surely he'd done something to me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Where's the man?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Alas here. I warrant you the poor fearful soul is scarce come to himself again yet. — if the fool have any wit he will apprehend me. — do you hear sir you may be bold to come forth; the fury that haunted you is gone.

div.stage: Fresco peeps fearfully forth from behind the arras.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: Are you sure he is gone?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: He's gone; he's gone, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: I would I were gone too. Has shook me almost into a dead palsy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How fell the difference between you?

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: I would I were out at the back door.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thou'rt safe enough. Prithee tell's the falling out.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p:
Yes sir, when I have recovered my spirits. My memory is almost frighted from me. — o so, so, so. — why sir, as I came along the street sir; — this same gentleman came stumbling after me, and trod o'my heel, —
I cried o. do you cry sirrah? says he. Let me see your heel; if it be not hurt, I'll make you cry for something. So he claps my head between his legs, and pulls off my shoe. I having shifted no socks in a sea 'Night, the gentleman cried foh; and said my feet were base and cowardly feet, they stunk for fear. Then he knocked my shoe about my pate, and I cried oh, once more. In the mean time comes a shag. haired dog by, and rubs against his shins. The gentleman took the dog in shag-hair to be some watchman in a rug gown; and swore he would hang me up at the next door with my lantern in my hand, that passengers might see their way as they went without rubbing against gentlemen's shins. So, for want of a cord. he took his own garters off; and as he was going to make a noose, I watched my time and ran away. And as I ran (Indeed) I bid him hang himself in his own garters. So he in choler, pursued me hither as you see.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why this savours of distraction.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Of mere distraction.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: howsoever it savours, I am sure it smells like a lie.

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.p: Thou mayst go forth at the back door (Honest fellow) the way is private and safe.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: So it had need, for your foredoor (Here) is both common and dangerous.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Good night honest Fresco.

sp.speaker: Fres.
sp.p: Good night madam; if you get me kissing o'ladies again. —

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: This falls out handsomely.
But yet the matter does not well succeed;
Till I have brought it to the very deed.

div.stage: Enter Charlemont in arms, a musquetier, and a sergeant.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Sergeant! what hour o'the night is't.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: About one.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I would you would relieve me; for I am
so heavy, that I shall ha'much ado;
To stand out my perdu.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I'll e'en but walk
The round (Sir) and then presently return.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: For God's sake sergeant relieve me, above five hours together in so foul a stormy night as this?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Why 'tis a music soldier. Heaven and earth are now in consort, when the thunder and the cannon play one to another.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: I know not why I should be thus inclined to sleep, I feel my disposition pressed with a necessity of heaviness. Soldier! if thou hast any better eyes, I prithee wake me when the sergeant comes.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Sir, 'tis so dark and stormy that I shall scarce either see or hear him e'er he comes upon me.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: I cannot force myself to wake. —

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Return to France; for thy old father's dead;
And thou by murder, disinherited.
Attend with patience the success of things;
But leave revenge unto the King of Kings.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: O my affrighted soul! what fearful dream
Was this that waked me? Dreams are but the raised
Impressions of premeditated things,
By serious apprehension left upon
Our minds, or else th'imaginary shapes
Of objects proper to th' complexion, or
The dispositions of our bodies. These
Can neither of them be the cause, why I
Should dream thus; for my mind has not been moved
With any one conception of a thought
To such a purpose; nor my nature wont
To trouble me with fantasies of terror.
It must be something that my genius would
Inform me of. Now gracious heaven forbid!
O! let my spirit be deprived of all
foresight and knowledge, ere it understand
That vision acted; or divine that act
To come. Why should I think so? Leave I not
My worthy father i'the kind regard
Of a most loving uncle? Soldier! sawest
No apparition of a man?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: You dream sir; I saw nothing.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Tush. These idle dreams
Are fabulous. Our boiling fantasies
Like troubled waters falsify the shapes
Of things retained in them; and make 'em seem
Confounded, when they are distinguished, so
My actions daily conversant with war;
(The argument of blood and death) had left
(Perhaps) th'imaginary presence of
Some bloody accident upon my mind:
Which mixed confusedly with other thoughts,
(Whereof th'remembrance of my father, might
Be one) presented all together, seem
Incorporate; as if his body were
The owner of that blood, the subject of
That death; when he's at Paris, and that blood
Shed here. It may be thus. I would not leave
The war, for reputation's sake, upon
An idle apprehension; a vain dream.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Stand. Stand, I say. No? Why then have at thee. Sir, if you will not stand, I'll make you fall? Nor stand, nor fall? Nay then the devil's dam has broke her husband's head: for sure it is a spirit, I shot it through, and yet it will not fall.

div.stage: The ghost approaches Charlemont. He fearfully avoids it.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: O pardon me! my doubtful heart was slow
To credit that which I did fear to know.

div.head: Actus tertii scaena prima.

sp.speaker: D'amville.
sp.l: Set down the body. Pay earth what she lent.
But she shall bear a living monument,
To let succeeding ages truly know.
That she is satisfied, what he did owe:
Both principal and use; because his worth
Was better at his death then at his birth.

div.stage: A dead march. Enter the funeral of Charlemont as a soldier.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: And with his body, place that memory
Of noble Charlemont his worthy son.
And give their graves the rites that do belong
To soldiers. They were soldiers both. The father
Held open war with sin; the son with blood:
This in a war more gallant that more good.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: There place their arms; and here their epitaphs.
And may these lines survive the last of graves.

lg.head: The epitaph of Montferrers.
lg.l: Here lie the ashes of that earth and fire;
Whose heat and fruit, dead feed and warm the poor :
And they (As if they would in sighs expire,
And into tears dissolve) his death deplore.
He did that good freely for goodness' sake,
Unforced: for generousness he held so dear,
That he feared none but him that did him make,
And yet he served him more for love then fear.
So's life provided, that though he did die
A death; yet died not suddenly.

lg.head: The epitaph of Charlement.
lg.l: His body lies interred within this would;
Who died a young man, yet departed old.
And in all strength of youth that man can have,
Was ready still to drop into his grave.
For aged in virtue with a youthful eye,
He welcomed it being still prepared to die;
And living so, though young deprived of breath,
He did not suffer an untimely death.
But we may say of his brave blessed decease :
He died in war; and yet he died in peace.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: O might that fire revive the ashes of
This phoenix! yet the wonder would not be
So great as he was good; and wondered at
For that. His life's example was so true
A practic of religion's theory;
That her divinity seemed rather the
Description than th'instruction of his life.
And of his goodness, was his virtuous son
A worthy imitator. So that on
These two Herculean pillars, where their arms
Are placed; there may be writ, non ultra. For
Beyond their lives as well for youth as age;
Nor young nor old, in merit or in name;
Shall e'er exceed their virtues or their fame.

div.l: 'Tis done. Thus fair accomplements, make foul
Deeds gracious. Charlemont! come now when t'wut.
I've buried under these two marble stones.
Thy living hopes; and thy dead father's bones.
div.stage: Enter Castabella mourning to the monument of Charlemont.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: O thou that knowest me justly Charlemonts.
Though in the forced possession of another;
Since from thine own free spirit we receive it,
That our affections cannot be compelled,
Though 'Our actions may; be not displeased, if on
The altar of his tomb, I sacrifice
My tears. They are the jewels of my love
Dissolved to grief: and fall upon
His blasted spring; as April dew, upon
A sweet young blossom shaked before the time.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Go see my trunks disposed of, I'll but walk
A turn or two i'th church and follow you.
O! here's the fatal monument of my
Dead father first presented to mine eye.
What's here? in memory of Charlemont?
Some false relation has abused belief.
I am deluded. But I thank thee heaven.
For ever let me be deluded thus.
My Castabella mourning o'er my hearse?
Sweet Castabella rise, I am not dead.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: O heaven defend me.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I beshrew my rash
And inconsiderate passion. — Castabella!
That could not think — my Castabella! — that
My sudden presence might affright her sense. —
I prithee (My affection) pardon me.
Reduce thy understanding to thine eye.
Within this habit which thy misinformed
Conceit takes only for a shape; live both
The soul and body of thy Charlemont.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: I feel a substance, warm, and soft, and moist,
Subject to the capacity of sense.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Which spirits are not; for their essence is
Above the nature and the order of
Those elements whereof our senses are
Created. Touch my lip. Why turnst thou from me?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Grief above griefs. That which should woe relieve,
Wished and obtained, gives greater cause to grieve.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Can Castabella think it cause of grief
That the relation of my death proves false?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: The presence of the person we affect,
(Being hopeless to enjoy him) makes our grief
More passionate than if we saw him not.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Why not enjoy? has absence changed thee?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Yes.
From maid to wife.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Art married?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: O I am.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Married had not my mother been a woman,
I should protest against the chastity
Of all thy sex. How can the merchant, or
The mariner absent whole years (From wife's
Experienced in the satisfaction of
Desire) promise themselves to find their sheets
Unspotted with adultery, at their
Return? when you that never had the sense
Of actual temptation; could not stay
A few short months.

sp.speaker: Caste.
sp.l: O do but hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: But thou wert wise; and didst consider that
A soldier might be maimed, and so (Perhaps)
Lose his hability to please thee.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: No. That weakness pleases me in him I have.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What? married to a man unable too?
O strange incontinence! Why? was thy blood
Increased to such a pleurisy of lust,
That of necessity, there must a vein
Be opened; though by one that had no skill
To do't?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you hear me.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Speak.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Heaven knows I am unguilty of this act.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Why? were't thou forced to do't?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Heaven knows I was.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: What villain did it?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Your uncle 'D'amville.
And he that dispossessed my love of you;
Hath disinherited you of possession.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Disinherited? wherein have I deserved
To be deprived of my dear father's love?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Both of his love and him. His soul's at rest.
But here your injured patience may behold
The signs of his lamented memory.
Has found it. When I took him for a ghost,
I could endure the torment of my fear;
More easily than I can his sorrows hear.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Of all men's griefs must mine be singular?
Without example? Here I met my grave.
And all men's woes are buried i' their graves
But mine. In mine my miseries are born.
I prithee sorrow leave a little room,
In my confounded and tormented mind;
For understanding to deliberate
The cause or author of this accident. —
A close advantage of my absence made,
To dispossess me both of land and wife:
And all the profit does arise to him,
By whom my absence was first moved and urged.
These circumstances (Uncle) tell me, you
Are the suspected author of those wrongs.
Whereof the lightest, is more heavy than
The strongest patience can endure to bear.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Now sir! your business?

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: My annuity.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Not a denier.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: How would you ha' me live?

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Why turn Cryer. Cannot you turn crier?

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Then do so, you've a good voice for't.
You're excellent at crying of a rape.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Sir, I confess in particular respect to yourself, I was somewhat forgetful. General honesty possessed me.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Go, thou'rt the base corruption of my blood; and like a tetter growes't unto my flesh.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Inflict any punishment upon me. The severity shall not discourage me, if it be not shameful; so you'll but put money i'my purse. The want of money makes a free spirit more mad than the possession does an usurer.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Not a farthing.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Would you ha' me turn purse-taker? 'tis the next way to do't. For want is like the rack; it draws a man to endanger himself to the gallows rather than endure it.

div.stage: Enter Charlemont, D'amville counterfaites to take him for a ghost.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: What art thou? Stay. Assist my troubled sense. My apprehension will distract me. Stay.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: What art thou? speak.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: The spirit of Charlemont.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: O stay! compose me. I dissolve.

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: No. 'tis profane. Spirits are invisible. 'tis the fiend i'the likeness of Charlemont. I will have no conversation with Sathan.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: The spirit of Charlemont? I'll try that.
Before God thou sayest true, thou'rt all spirit.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Go call the officers.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Thou'rt a villain; and the son of a villain.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: You lie.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Have at thee.
Revenge to thee I'll dedicate this work.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Hold Charlemont!
Let him revenge my murder, and thy wrongs,
To whom the justice of revenge belongs.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: You torture me between the passion of my blood, and the religion of my soul,

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: A good honest fellow.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: What? wounded? apprehend him. Sir; is this your salutation for the courtesy I did you when we parted last? You ha'forgot I lent you a thousand crowns. First, let him answer for this riot. When the law is satisfied for that; an an action for his debt shall clap him up again. I took you for a spirit; and I'll conjure you before I ha'done.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: No. I'll turn conjurer. Devil! within this circle, in the midst of all thy force and malice I conjure thee do thy worst.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Sir, I have got a scratch or two here for your sake. I hope you'll give me money to pay the surgeon.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.p: Borachio! fetch me a thousand crowns. I am content to countenance the freedom of your spirit when 'tis worthily employed. A god's name give behaviour the full scope of generous liberty; but let it not disperse and spend itself in courses of unbounded licence. Here, pay for your hurts.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p:
I thank you sir. — generous liberty. — that is to say, freely to bestow my habilities to honest purposes. Methinks I should not follow that instruction now; if having the
means to do an honest office for an honest fellow, I should neglect it. Charlemont lies in prison for a thousand crowns. And here I have a thousand crowns. Honesty tells me 'twere well done to release Charlemont. But discretion says I had much ado to come by this; and when this shall be gone I know not where to singer any more: especially if I employ it to this use, which is like to endanger me into my father's perpetual displeasure. And then I may go hang myself, or be forced to do that, will make another save me the labour. No matter. Charlemont! Thou gavest me my life and that's somewhat of a purer earth than gold as fine as it is. 'tis no courtesy I do thee but thankfulness. I owe thee it and I'll pay it. He sought bravely, but the officers dragged him villanously. Arrant knaves! for using him so discourteously; may the sins o'the poor people be so few, that you sha'not be able to spare so much out o'your gettings, as will pay for the hire of a lame starved hackney to ride to an execution. But go a foot to the gallows, and be hanged. May elder brothers turn good husbands, and younger brothers get good wives; that there be no need of debt-books, nor use of sergeants. May there be all peace but i'the war, and all charity but i'the devil; so that prisons may be turned to hospitals, though the officers live oath benevolence. If this curse might come to pass, the world would say, blessed be he that curseth.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I grant the heaven. Thy goodness doth command
Our punishments: but yet no further than
The measure of our sins. How should they else
Be just? Or how should that good purpose of
Thy justice take effect, by bounding men
Within the confines of humanity,
When our afflictions do exceed our crimes?
Then they do rather teach the barbarous world
Examples that extend her cruelties
Beyond their own dimensions; and instruct
Our actions to be more, more barbarous.
O my afflicted soul! How torment swells
Thy apprehension with profane conceit,
Against the sacred justice of my God?
Our own constructions are the authors of
Our misery. We never measure our
Conditions but with men above us in
Estate. So while our spirits labour to
Be higher than our fortunes they're more base.
Since all those attributes which make men seem
Superior to us; are man's subjects; and
Were made to serve him. The repining man
Is of a servile spirit to deject
The value of himself below their estimation.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Here. Take my sword. — how now my wild swaggerer? you're tame enough now; are you not? The penury of a prison is like a soft consumption. 'twill humble the pride of your mortality; and arm your soul in complete patience to endure the weight of affliction without feeling it. What? Hast no music in thee? Thou'st trebles and bases enough. Treble injury; and base usage. But trebles and bases make poor music without means. Thou wantest means; dost? what? Dost droop? art dejected?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: No sir. I have a heart above the reach
Of thy most violent maliciousness.
A fortitude in scorn of thy contempt;
(Since fate is pleased to have me suffer it)
That can bear more than thou hast power t'inflict.
I was a baron that thy father has
Deprived me off. In stead of that, I am
Created King. I've lost a signiory,
That was confined within a piece of earth;
A wart upon the body of the world.
But now I am an emperor of a world.
This little world of man. My passions are
My subjects; and I can command them laugh;
Whilst thou dost tickle 'em to death with misery.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: 'Tis bravely spoken; and I love thee for't. Thou liest here for a thousand crowns. Here are a thousand to redeem thee. Not for the ransom o'my life thou gavest me. That I value not at one crown. 'tis none o'my deed. Thank my father for't. 'tis his goodness. Yet he looks not for thanks. For he does it under hand; out of a reserved disposition to do thee good without ostentation. — out of great heart you'll refus't now; will you?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: No. Since I must submit myself to fate; I never will neglect the offer of one benefit; but entertain them as her favours; and th'inductions to some end of better fortune. As whose instrument; I thank thy courtesy.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Well, come along.

sp.speaker: D'am:
sp.l: Daughter you do not well to urge me. I
Ha'done no more than justice. Charlemont
Shall die and rot in prison; and 'tis just.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: O father! Mercy is an attribute
As high as justice; an essential part
Of his unbounded goodness, whose divine
Impression, form, and image man should bear.
And ( methinks ) man should love to imitate
His mercy; since the only countenance
Of justice, were destruction; if the sweet
And loving favour of his mercy did
Not mediate between it and our weakness.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Forbear. You will displease me. He shall rot.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Dear sir! Since by your greatness, you
Are nearer heaven in place; be nearer it
In goodness. Rich men should transcend the poor,
As clouds the earth; raised by the comfort of
The sun, to water dry and barren grounds.
If neither the impression in your soul
Of goodness; nor the duty of your place,
As goodness substitute; can move you: then
Let nature, which in savages, in beasts,
can stir to pity, tell you that he is
Your kinsman; —

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: You expose your honesty
To strange construction: why should you so urge
Release for Charlemont? Come you profess
More nearness to him than your modesty
Can answer. You have tempted my suspicion.
I tell thee he shall starve, and die, and rot.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Uncle, I thank you.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: Much good do it you. — who did release him?

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: D'am.
sp.l: You are a villain.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: You're my father.

sp.speaker: D'am.
